review_title: Great on-campus position for current students

Inside the Peerconnect services, you get the chance to meet other students & help build your soft skills while helping other peers. Management is very accommodating with your schedule and it's overall a great experience to boost your resume. Tons of resources available and you get the chance explore more in-depth all the iniciatives happening around campus.
cons: They make you pick areas to improve regarding your soft skills and feels a bit forced sometimes that you must focus on that. Once semester ends, there's a performance review about your goals and if/how you achieved them. Tons of work for a simple peer to peer service.

review_title: Great Position to have as a student
pros: Hours fit into your academic schedule. Most of the material and resources needed to teach/tutor students is readily available from previous peer leaders so there is no need to create new teaching material. The sessions run no more than 1 hour and more advanced sessions run for 2 hours.
cons: Sometimes students do not participate in these sessions as much (strangely you see this more in upper semesters where the material is more complex and dense) so it may feel you're pulling teeth. There are times students want to email you questions regarding material outside of the sessions but honestly I think that is simply part of the job.

pros: Good community with lots of benefits
cons: Lots of office politics. Depends on what area you’re in

review_title: A great team, but last-minute with communication
job_title: Part Time Professor in Toronto, ON
pros: As a new part-time professor, I found the staff and other faculty incredibly welcoming and friendly. It was a shame we had to pivot from in-person to online mid-semester, and I had to teach remotely, away from the college and the others who work there.
cons: Being a part-timer, when the pandemic hit and I was the last to know about schedule changes and teaching assignments. I was initially offered further courses to teach after a successful first semester, but I only found out a week before classes began that I was not needed this semester, and my course was being taught by someone else. This was after I received course materials to study and slides to use during lectures from another prof who had prepared everything as THEY were told they would be teaching the course earlier, but then it had been given to me! I totally understand the nature of staffing during a dramatic downturn in enrollment caused by the pandemic, but a little more notice would have been nice. It's really a small complaint, but led to my 4/5 rating instead of 5/5!

job_title: Digital Engagement Coordinator in Toronto, ON
pros: Great team, lots of growth, good benefits.
cons: Some team members may be inexperienced

pros: great coworkers and prime locations in Toronto
cons: zero benefits as part timer

review_title: Good for the Part-Time Teaching Experience
pros:
Refer to my headline. Thanks to GBC, I was lucky enough to be offered two part-time remedial English courses my first semester ever there.

Rate of pay significantly better than teaching ESL for private schools/academies. However, as always, not paid for grading/paperwork/helping students: only for in-class teaching hours.

My supervisor was good. And fair/reasonable, in terms of her assessments/comments/suggestions for improvement.
cons: Since the 2017 Ontario College Professor strike, part-time instructors are still non-unionized. Vote result: pro/con re: union might not yet have been announced as of mid-2021. (I haven't heard.) Partial load instructors seem to have gained good strike benefits. Due to seniority issues, seemingly they're prioritized for teaching courses. My understanding is that apparently, part-time instructors are considered only *after* all possible partial load have been asked/offered/refused. Understandable, but . . . one needs tons of other gigs to survive. It seems to be hard to get partial load teaching status -- at least if a generalist or relatively new to teaching. (Six years P-T: I broke into partial load just one semester: four courses -- luck more than anything -- and that was three years before the 2017 strike.) [These views based upon my comprehension of the situation when I spoke about it with my supervisor, late November, 2019.]

pros:
+ You get paid on time, and if you experience any issues, the payroll department tries to fix them fast
+ People are usually supportive of one another, especially since the pandemic hit hard and inter-departmental collaboration became prominent
+ The majority of lower-pyramid people try to make a difference for students 
+ Unionized
+ Free access to some software
+ Lots of room for error even for key roles (this is actually bad)
+ Most positions are relaxed jobs - although the work-from-home culture demanding an "always accessible" attitude (just as in any other place that was not ready for a swift shift)
cons:
- Pandemic has proven how unprepared the college was for a tech-driven future
- Upper management increased their salaries while cutting support staff jobs, turning important jobs into incapable software interactions, or dropping on other staff's shoulders as extra work without extra pay
- All words, no support when it comes to mental health. The employee support company they provide is abysmal at best
- Pay is below average when compared to other colleges
- Always playing the catch game rather than pioneering. Always waiting for another school to take action before moving a finger
- The support staff was literally told to see being laid-off as an opportunity while the upper management said they would not be cutting their own salary raise to support the fiscal gap in the same town hall meeting
- Even before the pandemic, this class-difference entitled behavior was apparent - like upgrading the management level toilets rather than the public - student-facing ones
- Infrastructure causes more job friction than easing work
- Some departments are impossible to reach, always requiring managers CC'ed to emails to accomplish even the most basic tasks
- Support staff is stuck between sunshine list managers who do not want to risk their job and either stay silent and passive or act as paper pushers for the most part, and staff trying to accomplish things for students who continuously state they are not in the right place since the pandemic hit
- Nothing happens fast
- Most projects are just for appearance and would be case studies for project management students on how not to do things. Working on something that sounds good on paper meanwhile the most basic of systems fail
- International students are admitted into programs they would not be successful just for money without any proper filtering system. It turned the school into an international student mill
- No health care or paid sick leave for part-time employees, hiding behind the collective agreement excuses or government legislations meanwhile other colleges openly deny these and assist their employees
- Heavily relies on and promotes location. This is not a hotel; it is a school
- Close to zero chance for support staff to be realized and promoted unless you network more than you work
- No equal pay for equal work for the part-time staff

review_title: A good place to do good work.
pros: Having an impact on learners transitioning to a new career or new level of a career is incredibly rewarding. As a unionized workplace, the pay is fair and benefits are good. Some roles have flexibility which those looking after others appreciate. Staff and faculty can take GBC courses very cheaply, though few have time to do so.
cons: You won't get rich and in this city it would be difficult to maintain a middle class lifestyle - purchase a home, raise a kid or two, etc. - less than 45 minutes from any GBC campus without a second income contributing, too. As a college, unionized faculty and staff have to bargain every few years and so security cannot be taken for granted, and raises are limited to the first four years, then dependent on contract negotiations. Pay is directed at a provincial level, but this is the most urban college of the 24 in Ontario, so pay relative to cost of living is very low at GBC.

review_title: This is a terrible place for partial load or part time staff.
job_title: Part Time Professor in Toronto, ON
pros: You can make a decent wage for part time work here and get decent benefits if you work on a partial load contract
cons: art timers are not treated well, union rules are not respected, any additional expertise you may have to contribute is disregarded; once upon a time ago, they couldn't get part time staff in the office fast enough. Now even part time work has become political. Clerks do the teaching assignments, and if you look at someone the wrong way and don't keep your mouth shut, you'll be out of a job next term. AS it is, you never know if you have a job next term anyhow, and there is much favoritism in how partial load assignments are given out. If you must work there, get your experience, and get out. The odds of you getting hired are extremely low, and if you stay there too long, you'll get pidgeon holed in one area and never be able to work anywhere else.

pros: It is a multi-cultural environment where respect for identity is crucial.  Employees are usually service-driven, making easy to approach any colleague. Inclusion and accessibility are really important, and they are present not only in the facilities, but in all the communication and work culture.  After 7 years working for the company, I have rarely seen colleagues working extra-hours, so this is good for family-oriented people.
cons:
It is a conservative environment, so hierarchies are really predominant. Internal communication to employees (specifically for contract termination, etc) are share at the last minute. 
It is a unionized environment, so when you are out of the union, you really feel it (not in a good way). There is a huge difference in contract conditions for full-time and part-time employees. It is extremely hard to create new job positions. On the other hand, there are jobs that are posted forever as they are back-up seats in case a unionized employee losses his/her job.

pros: It is an active education, practical college that cares about its employees and students in different aspects for example the follow up and survey that if  employees are satisfy with their situations and taking an action about/if there is an issue.
cons: As a part time employee I have to worry about if my contract is going to continue or not, the job is not guaranteed although I am doing my best and punting so much effort and passion on my job.    And I can not get an insurance and I do not get the same benefit in compare with full time employees. Although it is an almost the issue of most of part time employees in other job placement too, but still needs to be reviewed and solved.

review_title: Expediency in hiring hampers students best interests
job_title: Part Time Instructor in Toronto, ON
pros: Management trusts instructors to deliver, getting involved only in very extreme situations. Instructors are very supportive, sharing materials and best teaching practices quite freely. The college maintains integrity in academics, learning and evaluation is challenging, and student needs are supported outside the classroom. The college is continuously expanding into new buildings and programs, and planning ahead for growth.
cons: Investment in hiring full time instructors has been in rapid decline for about 5 years. Same holds true for lab equipment and technology. The results are being felt in many departments. Part-time instructors are hired with days to spare and cannot prep for classes adequately. Management prefers to rely on a pool of talent they can call on, and not commit to instructors.

review_title: Opens doors, but run by  people with no integrity
pros:
- good work life balance
 - the work I was doing was amazing, meaningful and exactly what pI wanted to be doing.  I was very passionate about it
cons:
- My VP and direct manager would step over their own mothers to get ahead.  No integrity and they definitely didn't care about students.  Just the bottom line.  This seems to come from the President down.  
- Like most HR departments, they will turn on you if your manager wants them to, despite saying, they're there for you.
- I was partial load but often asked to work unpaid overtime, violating the collective bargaining agreement for unionized staff.
- I was asked to alter professor's content without their consent.

review_title: Overall a great place to work
job_title: User Service Representative in Toronto, ON
pros:
- Amazing for those who want to help people and love interacting with them
- Real community vibe with fun get-togethers and events
- Paid training - learn by doing on the job
- Big discounts for any college courses you want to take as a continuing education student
- Great gym at St. James Campus! Part-timers and Full-timers get free access
cons:
- Unionized organization
- Hard and long to become full-time if first hired part-time
- Part-time contract is reviewed and renewed three times a year (every semester), mine was not renewed because of full-time studies, and, as a result, lesser availability 
- Even if part-time, hard to combine with another part-time job because schedules change every week, so it's hard to know when you are going to get scheduled and make other commitments without losing hours at the College

pros:
+ Very friendly and caring middle management.
+ No after hours, no extra work
+ Always on-time payment with no hustle
+ Dynamic work environment with a chance to improve people skills
+ You can pick your hours
cons:
- Minimum wage
- Upper college management doesn't care much about anything (like giving the best service award to the tutoring centre, meanwhile cutting their budget at the same time)
-  Half the time tutoring turns into teaching due to the lack of students' base knowledge, and it makes you wonder how these students passed their evaluations in the first place
- Some students can be very rude
- Pretty much a dead end for in-house career advancement

pros: Freedom to conduct classes how you see fit -  what to cover provided it fits within course outline.  Although no requirement to follow the established textbook,  it seems a shame to have students purchase the manual and not make use of it.
cons: No support and fellow instructors are not helpful. Sensed everyone felt they were at risk of having credit stolen from them if they shared information with others.   You are left to figure it out for yourself.

pros: Love the staff, love the students, love being a part of this college's great reputation, love being able to take courses there
cons: Would love to get equal time in the day classes as I do in the CE classes.  CE courses do not run all the time due to lack of enrollment and this is difficult to then schedule my life around.   Hourly should be more competitive with other schools and part-time day professors.

pros: it a good place to work at

office politics, partiality, I knew somebody was too good and fast with her work and the seniors working in the same position were scared of her getting promotion so they said things about her to the manager and got her contract ended

If you are on part time you still worked and have experience but if you apply again for the job or similar job they dont take you even if you were good

-great location and central downtown of Toronto 
-a lot of services able for students
- i have worked part-time for the school during the 2 semesters, and it is minimum wage and really flexible with ur school schedule for that extra cash during the school year.
cons:
-social and school events could be better especially for school of design.
-extracurricular activities could be advertised better for students who want to be involved as well 
-student clubs could be better too

review_title: Administration comes in the way of education
pros: Access to a great facility and enthusiast students. Opportunity to connect with and create meaningful impact on the lives of young professionals.
cons: Everything you read on the state of academic institutions and their administration is true and applies here too. Incompetent administration that comes in the way of education and student's interests. Unbearable inequality between contract staff who carry the load and unionized  full timers who can get away with anything (unethical and illegal activities as well).

pros: Flexibility - great benefits- summers- teaching. It's like not working in Toronto but you are in downtown Toronto. Work life balance. Every day is different. Strong union. Fresh talent in teaching pool with recent real work experience.
cons: Marking papers time consuming- some people slack - take advantage of a strong union. A lot of fresh talent and a lot of curmudgeons who have been mailing it in for years, makes for a dynamic work environment.

pros:
- Great system to develop English & Math Skill through the interactve tutoring, Skill development Workshop, and shared cases in forum.

- Amazing co-workers and Mutl-talented Advisors, all of employees are supportive and positive in all situtation to provide great accademical services in the wake of in-class lectures.

- Events and activities by motivated and friendly co-tutors
cons: - Some could get frustrated low wage. However, if employees vision is to support the other students, the wage should not to be vital matter.

pros: Great atmosphere, positive work culture, great people. If you are hired full time, benefits are amazing
cons: Limited available full-time positions. Most people are contract or part-time workers who do not receive any benefits.

job_title: Report Assistant in Casa Loma, ON
pros: It's one of the best colleges in Ontario. There is a good access to all buildings when using public transportation.
cons: I really don't see any major problem. I have very good co-workers who are very caring, polite, and knowledgeable. Maybe payment could be a little bit better.

pros:
-Fellow staff and faculty are generally very nice people
-Comfortable working hours
-Lots of other College perks
cons:
-Management very top down
-Slow to adapt new practices, policies
-St James campus very political atmosphere due to too many big-wigs stationed there.  Casa Loma and Waterfront campus atmospherers MUCH more relaxed.

pros: Great work-life balance - as a student employee, they work around my schedule and it's expected that school is my top priority. Great work atmosphere too.
cons: The pay isn't much and there are so many levels of administration that it's sometimes a bit of a headache to figure out what you're supposed to do, but that's working in a school for you.

job_title: Health Information Management Technician in Toronto, ON
pros:
-Get to work with amazing people who are understanding and filled with knowledge
-Get to interact with students on a daily basis and share my experience, strength and hope with them with regards to the HIM field
-I feel eager and excited every morning to go into work, it's not a job it's a new experience every day
cons: -This job does not have any cons

pros: Good salary and benefits.  Can attend  classes for free.  Paid sabbaticals are available. Defined benefit pension plan.  Opportunity to work in many areas within the college.
cons: Oppressive workplace culture.  No work life balance.  Managers do not practice what they preach. Cannot transfer seniority to other colleges in the system.

pros: Stable, old style job for life academic hires.
cons: Place should be pensioned off. Academic and management staff old, lame, tired.

review_title: George brown college child care - ECE
job_title: Registered Early Childhood Educator in Toronto, ON
pros:
- Competitive wage $28~
- Part time staff tuition discount (you can take continuing education/part time program, only $20 per course 
- vacation fee
- various workshop opportunities
cons:
- hard to get a full time position (very competitive, lots of part-time & contact staff) 
- hard to move to other job fields

pros: Really great people work here! Fun and engaging work environment. Many opportunities for professional development.
cons: Departments disconnected from each other. Hard to know about what other departments are involved with, what initiatives are on-going, who is partnering with whom.

pros: Co-worker are respectful and extends their help in any situation that you need help with in performing the job that was assigned to you.  My manager treats me with respect and allows me ample time to finish a job that was assigned to me.
cons: None that I have experienced.

pros: I had an opportunity to developed my abilities as Videographer creating, editing and producing with quality all videos for website and social media platforms that increase the numbers of video viewers.
cons: Even though I enjoyed work independently, I would be happy if I had a second hand in some interviews.

pros:
- great pay and work environment
- lots of room for growth
- excellent work-life balance
- upgraded fitness centre and gym that is free for staff
cons:
- inconsistent work load
- slow to make structural and administrative changes

job_title: Assistant to the Chair in Toronto, ON
pros:
Great first job out of school.
Decent salary for young professionals.
Reasonable work environment.
cons:
Painfully slow career advancement.

Too many unqualified and unskilled people hired only because of politics or education. 

Chaotic operational infrastructure.

Organization has a poor strategic vision.

review_title: Student Support Member to promote well-being.
pros: Got the opportunity to help students and got to know people at school. Had flexible hours, everyone was kind to each other, gained many skills and contributed to making the campus a safer place.
cons: This job only runs through the school year and not summer.

pros: Chill environment. You can work at your own pace given that you provide notes within 24 hours.
cons: Delayed pays. Email is the only form of communication about the payroll. Sometimes pay can delay upto 3 months after you've covered 15 hours worth of classes.

review_title: Maximum hours when they need you, nothing when it's quite - don't rely on
pros: Friendly atmosphere, suitable schedule, not difficult duties
cons: your hours can be cut to zero if they don't need people when the rush weeks passed

pros: Helping people with use of workout equipment. Flexible with work hours.
cons: Gym was small and there was not enough equipment. Capacity of 30 people to use workout area. Superiors in athletic department will literally leave you in charge of whole athletic department (gym/offices) at times.

pros:
- PeerConnect felt like a family. 
- I learned a lot about developing my soft skills. 
- Instilled confidence in myself and other.
cons: - GBC is super slow if you want to start acting on an idea  prepare to wait for a semester when they review it.

review_title: Working with students is a lot of fun
pros: Get to know a lot of new people every once a while. Very dynamic environment.
cons: Occasionally you see a few jerks among students.

pros: I was able to work with my team at the hours we were available to complete our target.  GBC is very flexible in this way if you are working part-time depending on your project or area you worked with.
cons: Pay is minimal and can improve

pros: Amazing people, great location, staff discounts for education are amazing. Pay in lieu of benefits. CAAT Pension is matched at approximately 9%.
cons: Salary, although fair, could be better.  No benefits for contract workers.

job_title: Library Assistant in Casa Loma, ON
pros: It is great to work in George Brown College. It has a very friendly environment and everyone are always helping each other. I feel homely and always connected.

pros: I work with a wonderful team and get to help an awesome set of students. The environment is very supportive and I get to work in a field I am passionate about.
cons: The college is very large and can be hard to navigate.

job_title: College and Career Coach in Toronto, ON
pros: Many opportunities to access learning for almost no cost. Lots of committees and projects to get involved with. Competitive salary. Pension and good benefits.
cons: Can take time to secure a full time role.

pros: Friendly coworkers, flexible schedules, high hourly pay.
cons: Will not allow part-timers to work more than 24 hours per week, hours vary widely from week to week. Few to no hours during break weeks and exam weeks.  Very little opportunity for promotion.

pros: Great team approach - wonderful environment - love working with students in the clinic and calibrating with other instructors!
cons: None really - other than wishing we could work more hours!

pros:

pros: Great benefits, yearly raises, good work life balance, lots of room to move up. Discounted education, and beautiful facility
